{{italic title}} '''''Elementa harmonica''''' is a [[treatise]] on the subject of [[musical scales]] by [[Aristoxenus]], of which substantial amounts are [[Extant literature|extant]].
==Dating== The work dates apparently to c.[[300 B.C.]]<ref>[http://www.rotman.uwo.ca/what-we-do/ Rotman Institute of Philosophy] Western University [Retrieved 2015-05-04]</ref>
==Title== {{Main|Harmony#Etymology and definitions|Harmonic}}
The work is known variously as Aristoxenou (or Aristoxenoy) Armonika (or Harmonika) Stoicheia ''i.e.'' Aristoxenou Armonika Stoicheia, Aristoxenou Harmonika Stoicheia etc. All of these translate as ''The Harmonics of Aristoxenus''. ''Elementa harmonica'' translates as Elements of Harmonics.<ref name="M.C. Howatson">{{cite book |url=|author=M.C. Howatson|title=The Oxford Companion to Classical Literature |page=73|publisher=Oxford University Press (reprint) |date=22 Aug 2013 |isbn=0199548552}} ''Oxford Paperback Reference'' </ref><ref name="Aristoxenus, Henry Stewart Macran">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3TseQjV_wogC&pg=PA165&lpg=PA165&dq=translations+of+Aristoxenus+Elements+of+Harmony&source=bl&ots=aDzoOJl1aD&sig=n4ldPcu--zEZ_Kzxv_8MuCe73oY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=dL5GVcH6JdjiasmTgPgM&ved=0CCAQ6AEwADgU#v=onepage&q=translations%20of%20Aristoxenus%20Elements%20of%20Harmony&f=false|author=Aristoxenus, Henry Stewart Macran|title=Harmonika Stoicheia (The Harmonics of Aristoxenus)|publisher=Georg Olms Verlag |year=1902 |isbn=3487405105|accessdate=2015-05-04}}(and [http://www.worldcat.org/title/aristoxenoy-armonika-stoicheia-the-harmonics-of-aristoxenus/oclc/123175755 World Cat])</ref><ref>The Perseus Catalog - [http://catalog.perseus.org/catalog/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0088.tlg001 Elementa Harmonica] Tufts University , University of Leipzig [Retrieved 2015-05-04]</ref> The work is otherwise rendered as The Elements, or Elements, the latter translates into Greek as Στοιχεία.<ref name="A.D. Barker"/>
==Subject==
===Historical context=== The Elements is held to be the work founding a tradition of the study of music based on practice, which is, to understand music by study to the ear. [[Musicology]] as a discipline achieved nascency with the systematic study undertaken in the work, which treated music independently of those prior studies which held it in a position of something purely and only in relation to an understanding of the ''[[Wikt:kosmos|kosmos]]''. In-as-much, the Elements is the first and earliest work on music in the classical Greek tradition. Earliest considerations arose within the [[Pythagorean school]] c.500 and thinking dwelled on the mathematical nature of harmonia. Aristotle, whose [[Peripatetic school]] Aristoxenus belonged to, addressed the subject in his work ''[[On the Soul]]''. Dewhitt thinks Aristoxenus treatment of the subject was essentially to attempt to describe and locate the elements of the soul, and provide mathematical proofs for these. Aristoxenus is thought contrary to the position of the Pythagoreans, he favoured an intellectual treatment of the subject which Aristotle had set out in his work, which is the exercise of [[inductive logic]] with attention to [[empirical evidence]].<ref name="C.H. Kahn">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5vi10r5k5eEC&pg=PA69&dq=Aristoxenus+Elements+Harmony&hl=en&sa=X&ei=m2RHVdHVFYrxaveEgJgI&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q=Aristoxenus%20Elements%20Harmony&f=false|author=C.H. Kahn|title=Pythagoras and the Pythagoreans: A Brief History |page=69|publisher=Hackett Publishing |date=1 Jan 2001 |isbn=0872205754| accessdate=2015-05-04}}</ref><ref>Sophie Gibson - [https://books.google.com/books?id=JAUSBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA3&dq=Aristoxenus+of+Tarentum+and+the+Birth+of+Musicology&hl=en&sa=X&ei=93pFVZGqMIixaerCgLgG&ved=0CCEQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Aristoxenus%20of%20Tarentum%20and%20the%20Birth%20of%20Musicology&f=false Aristoxenus of Tarentum and the Birth of Musicology (p.6)] Routledge, 8 Apr 2014 ''Studies in Classics'' {{ISBN|1135877475}} [Retrieved 2015-05-03]</ref><ref name="C.A. Huffman">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LZDBAgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Aristoxenus&hl=en&sa=X&ei=d-9FVbWeMdfhauPfgYgN&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Aristoxenus&f=false|author=C.A. Huffman|title=Aristoxenus of Tarentum: Discussion|publisher=Transaction Publishers, 2012 |accessdate=2015-05-03}}(p.254)</ref><ref name="H Partch">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w-eqL7oLyigC&pg=PA365&dq=Aristoxenus+Elements&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KFFHVbOWLsfiaP-RgYgD&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Aristoxenus%20Elements&f=false|author=H Partch|title=Genesis of a Music: An Account of a Creative Work, Its Roots, and Its Fulfillments|publisher=Da Capo Press |date=5 Aug 2009 |isbn=0786751002| accessdate=2015-05-04}}</ref><ref name="J. Hawkins"/><ref name="Mitzi Dewhitt">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pyZduhclFkoC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Aristoxenus&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-WpGVeejIcitadDAgLgP&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Aristoxenus&f=false|author=Mitzi Dewhitt|title=Aristoxenus's Ghost|publisher=Xlibris Corporation |date=7 Sep 2004 |isbn=1465332057| accessdate=2015-05-03}}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=January 2018}}</ref><ref name="L.M. Zbikowski Associate Professor of Music University of Chicago">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YSk-LjJNp8QC&pg=PA11&dq=Elementa+Harmonica&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_2xGVajOO4_paMO4gaAG&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Elementa%20Harmonica&f=false|author=L.M. Zbikowski Associate Professor of Music University of Chicago|title=Conceptualizing Music : Cognitive Structure, Theory, and Analysis: Cognitive Structure, Theory, and Analysis|publisher=Oxford University Press |date=18 Oct 2002 |isbn=019803217X | accessdate=2015-05-03}} ''AMS Studies in Music Series'' </ref><ref name="D.M. Randel">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=02rFSecPhEsC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Harvard+Dictionary+of+Music&hl=en&sa=X&ei=k9pHVdG7OovW7AamiYHgAw&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=The%20Harvard%20Dictionary%20of%20Music&f=false|author=D.M. Randel|title=The Harvard Dictionary of Music|publisher=Harvard University Press, ''Volume 16 of Harvard University Press reference library'' |year=2003 |isbn=0674011635| |page=358 |accessdate=2015-05-04}}</ref>
Aristoxenus is thought the first to consider music in this respect, as a separate subject, due to this work.<ref>Lilian Voudouri</ref>
===Description=== The work is a theoretical treatise concerned with [[harmony]] and harmonics, and thus pertains to a burgeoning theory of [[euphonics]]. The study of harmonics is especially concerned with treating melody in order to find its components (the Greek word for melody is μέλος).<ref name="A.D. Barker">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bVWcAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA163&lpg=PA163&dq=Burnyeat+translation+Aristoxenus&source=bl&ots=oMNm22fkQa&sig=syq1MR_GGSedkD7EdhZGmg5-tiU&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Ms5MVb6OCMXX7Qap2oMw&ved=0CEQQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=Burnyeat%20translation%20Aristoxenus&f=false|author=A.D. Barker|title=The Oxford Classical Dictionary (edited by S Hornblower, A Spawforth, E Eidinow) |page=163–164|publisher=Oxford University Press |date=29 Mar 2012 |isbn=0199545561| accessdate=2015-05-08}}</ref><ref name="Mitzi Dewhitt"/><ref name="D Obbink">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KBNGAH9-0YAC&pg=PA140&dq=Aristoxenus+Elements+Harmony&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MnNHVYK7AYfxaIPFgegC&ved=0CB8Q6AEwADgU#v=onepage&q=Aristoxenus%20Elements%20Harmony&f=false|author=D Obbink|title=Philodemus and Poetry : Poetic Theory and Practice in Lucretius, Philodemus and Horace |page=140|publisher=Oxford University Press |date=9 May 1995 |isbn=0195358546| accessdate=2015-05-04}}(additionally using ''American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, Fifth Edition'' at thefreedictionary.com)</ref>
In the first sentence of the treatise Aristoxenus identifies Harmony as belonging under the general scope of the study of the science of [[Melody]]. Aristoxenus considers notes to fall along a continuum available to [[auditory perception]]. Aristoxenus identified the three tetrachords in the treatise as ''[[diatonic|diatonic'', the ''chromatic]]'', and the ''[[enharmonic]]''.<ref name="M.C. Howatson"/><ref name="Aristoxenus, Henry Stewart Macran"/><ref>Cristiano M.L. Forster - [http://www.chrysalis-foundation.org/Philolaus_and_Euclid.htm Musical Mathematics : on the art and science of acoustic instruments CHAPTER 10: WESTERN TUNING THEORY AND PRACTICE] Chrysalis Foundation [Retrieved 2015-05-04]</ref>
The general considered attitude of Aristoxenus was to attempt an empirical study based therefore upon observation. In-as-much his writing contains criticisms of predecessing appreciations and attitudes, of the Pythagorean and ''harmonikoi'', on the problems of sound percptable as music.<ref name="R Katz, C Dahlhaus"/><ref name="J Godwin">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1WpnAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT402&dq=Aristoxenus+Elements+Harmony&hl=en&sa=X&ei=m2RHVdHVFYrxaveEgJgI&ved=0CEcQ6AEwBzgK#v=onepage&q=Aristoxenus%20Elements%20Harmony&f=false|author=J Godwin|title=The Harmony of the Spheres: The Pythagorean Tradition in Music|publisher=Inner Traditions / Bear & Co |date=1 Nov 1992 |isbn=1620550962| accessdate=2015-05-04}}</ref><ref name=" A. Barker"/>
==Editions== Translation into Latin for the first time, during 1564, was made by [[Antonius Gogavinus]].<ref name="S.J. Livesey (John of Reading)">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eLFulMIdGjAC&pg=PA25&dq=Aristoxenus+Elements&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1FlHVaKnEJLSaOeCgLAB&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Aristoxenus%20Elements&f=false|author=S.J. Livesey (John of Reading)|title=Theology and Science in the Fourteenth Century: Three Questions on the Unity and Subalternation of the Sciences from John of Reading's Commentary on the Sentences |page=25|publisher=BRILL |year=1989 |isbn=9004090231| accessdate=2015-05-04}}</ref>
Editions were published by Meibom, Marquard (1868) Aristoxenou harmonikōn ta sōzomena: Die harmonischen fragmente des Aristoxenus, published in Greek and German translation, and Westphal. Henry Stewart Macran edition was published during 1902 by Clarendon Press, Oxford. An edition was published in Latin during 1954, and another in the same year in Italian, by ''Typis Publicae Officinae Polygraphicae''.<ref name=" A. Barker"/><ref>Aristoxenus, P Marquard - [https://books.google.com/books?id=-dyxQXD4cdIC&redir_esc=y Aristoxenou harmonikōn ta sōzomena: Die harmonischen fragmente des Aristoxenus] Weidmann, 1868 [Retrieved 2015-05-04]</ref><ref>H.S. Macran - [https://archive.org/details/harmonicsofarist00aris The harmonics of Aristonexus] The Boston Library Consortium - Northeastern University Libraries [Retrieved 2015-05-04]</ref><ref>[[the Internet Archive]] - [https://openlibrary.org/books/OL14785002M/Elementa_harmonica Open Library ID : OL14785002M] ''University of Toronto MARC record'' [Retrieved 2015-05-08]</ref>
==History of scholarship==
===Pre-modern=== [[Vitruvius]] (circa. mid-20s [[Anno Domini|B.C.]] <ref>I. Kagis McEwen - [https://books.google.com/books?id=py5-XdtZQK4C&printsec=frontcover&dq=Vitruvius&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiT7cP429_JAhVB2hoKHUoADC0Q6AEILzAC#v=onepage&q=Vitruvius&f=false Vitruvius: Writing the Body of Architecture], [[MIT Press]] 2003, p.1 of 493 pages, {{ISBN|026263306X}} [Retrieved 2015-12-16]</ref>) based his understanding of the laws of harmony on the Elements of Aristoxenus.<ref>D.K.S. Walden - [http://booksandjournals.brillonline.com/content/journals/10.1163/22129758-12341255 Frozen Music: Music and Architecture in Vitruvius’ De Architectura 2014] Greek and Roman Musical Studies, Volume 2, Issue 1, pages 124 – 145 DOI: 10.1163/22129758-12341255 [Retrieved 2015-05-04]</ref>
The Elements was studied seriously and earnestly during [[the Renaissance]], by theoreticians and musicians,<ref name="R Katz, C Dahlhaus">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=64ADtnjmEpQC&pg=PA272&dq=Aristoxenus+Elements+Harmony&hl=en&sa=X&ei=TM1GVb76JYfbaNOegYAI&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Aristoxenus%20Elements%20Harmony&f=false|author=R Katz, C Dahlhaus|title=Contemplating Music: Substance|publisher=| accessdate=2015-05-04}}(p.273)</ref> because of the necessary choice which Renaissance intellectuals and thinkers had to make of deciding where to make concordance with, of the reality of the theory on music made by either Pythagoras or Aristoxenus.<ref>J. Prins - [https://books.google.com/books?id=XXWjBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA56&dq=Aristoxenus+the+Renaissance&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjAhNbb4t_JAhVCOhoKHZX6C5kQ6AEINDAC#v=onepage&q=Aristoxenus%20the%20Renaissance&f=false Echoes of an Invisible World: Marsilio Ficino and Francesco Patrizi on Cosmic Order and Music Theory] BRILL, 28 Nov 2014, 476 pages, History, {{ISBN|9004281762}}, ''Brill's Studies in Intellectual History'' [Retrieved 2015-12-16]</ref> All the events belonging to the Renaissance Period as an approximate whole occurred within a time some time prior to and including the 15th and 16th centuries <ref>P. Van Ness Myers - [http://www.shsu.edu/~his_ncp/Renn.html facsimile of ''Mediæval and Modern History'' published by Boston: Ginn and Company, 1905 - p.251] published online by [[Sam Houston State University]] [Retrieved 2015-12-16]</ref>
The work was known to [[Marcus Meibomius|Meibomius]],<ref name="J. Hawkins">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-wYVAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA66&dq=Aristoxenus+Elements&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KFFHVbOWLsfiaP-RgYgD&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Aristoxenus%20Elements&f=false|author=J. Hawkins|title=General history of the science and practice of music. [With] vol. of portraits, Volume 1|publisher=J.Alfred Novello 1858| accessdate=2015-05-04}}</ref> who was born 1611.<ref>[[Alexander Chalmers]] - [https://books.google.com/books?id=v-9HAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA11&dq=meibomius&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjh0ILL7d_JAhVJvBQKHYKkAawQ6AEIRzAH#v=onepage&q=meibomius&f=false The General biographical dictionary], Printed for J. Nichols 1815, ''Volume 22 of The General Biographical Dictionary: Containing an Historical and Critical Account of the Lives and Writings of the Most Eminent Persons in Every Nation'' (Original from the [[University of Michigan]] Digitized 31 Aug 2007) [Retrieved 2015-12-16]</ref>
===Modern=== Loloy made a study which was published during 1904. [[Annie Bélis]] composed a study Aristoxene de Tarante et Aristote: Le Traité d’harmonique, Études et commentaires 100, published during 1986.<ref>Lilian Voudouri - [http://www.mmb.org.gr/page/default.asp?la=2&id=1684 Music Library of Greece] Friends of Music Society (Athens) [Retrieved 2015-05-04]</ref>
[[Norman Cazden]] wrote the article ''Pythagoras and Aristoxenos Reconciled'' which was published 1958 by the Journal of Music Theory.<ref name="M Litchfield">{{cite book |url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/843385?uid=3738032&uid=2&uid=4&sid=21106261945551|author=M Litchfield|title=Aristoxenus and Empiricism: A Reevaluation Based on His Theories|publisher=Journal of Music Theory Vol. 32, No. 1 (Spring, 1988), pp. 51-73 ''Published by: Duke University Press''| accessdate=2015-05-04}}</ref><ref name="N Cazden">{{cite book |url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/829897?uid=3738032&uid=2&uid=4&sid=21106261945551|author=N Cazden|title=Pythagoras and Aristoxenos Reconciled|publisher=Journal of the American Musicological Society Vol. 11, No. 2/3 (Summer - Autumn, 1958), pp. 97-105 ''Published by: University of California Press''| accessdate=2015-05-04}}</ref>
W.B.Stanford' ''The Sound of Greek'' (1967) cites the work.<ref>T.G.Rosenmeyer - [https://books.google.com/books?id=x7G829b2__MC&pg=PA221&dq=Aristoxenus+Elements&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1FlHVaKnEJLSaOeCgLAB&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Aristoxenus%20Elements&f=false Elegiac and Elegos (in) ''California Studies in Classical Antiquity, Volume 1'' (p.221)] University of California Press & Cambridge University Press (ed. T.S.Brown, W.K.Pritchett)[Retrieved 2015-05-04]</ref>
[[Andrew Barker (classicist)|Andrew Barker]] has made a translation, published in ''Greek Musical Writings'' (volume 1 published 1984, volume 2 1989).<ref name="T.J. Mathiesen">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Td5odzctae8C&pg=PA306&dq=Meibom,+Marquard,+Westphal&hl=en&sa=X&ei=gbVGVdG-FoXcasejgYAF&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Meibom%2C%20Marquard%2C%20Westphal&f=false|author=T.J. Mathiesen|title=Apollo's Lyre: Greek Music and Music Theory in Antiquity and the Middle Ages|publisher=University of Nebraska Press, ACLS Humanities E-Book ''Volume 2 of Center for the History of Music Theory and Literature Bloomington, Ind: Publications of the Center for the History of Music Theory and Literature''|year=1999 |isbn=0803230796|accessdate=2015-05-04}}</ref><ref>A. Barker - [http://www.birmingham.ac.uk/staff/profiles/caha/barker-andrew.aspx staff profile] University of Birmingham [Retrieved 2015-05-04]</ref>
Landels' ''Music in Ancient Greece and Rome'' (1999) deals with intervals in ''The Elements''.<ref name="A Briggman"/>
Kuntz (2000) thinks Aristoxenus to have provided a superior understanding to the Pythagorean treatment of the harmonic problem.<ref>P.G. Kuntz - [http://www.religion-online.org/showarticle.asp?title=3005 Whitehead’s Category of Harmony: Analogous Meanings in Every Realm of Being and Culture - part.XX] Process Studies, pp.43-65, Vol. 29, Number 1, Spring-Summer, 2000. Process Studies is published quarterly by the Center for Process Studies [Retrieved 2015-05-04]</ref>
D Creese 2012 work concerns itself with Aristoxenus' consideration of the perfect fourth.<ref>D Creese - [http://www.ncl.ac.uk/historical/research/publication/184902 Instruments and Empiricism in Aristoxenus' Elementa harmonica] Newcastle University - School of History Classics and Archaeology 2012 [Retrieved 2015-05-04]</ref>
==Structure== The work comprises 3 books. Book II seems not to follow from Book I, and it is quite widely but not unanimously assumed that Book I is a separate work from Book II & III.<ref name=" A. Barker">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xRM9WLpswiEC&pg=PA113&dq=Elementa+Harmonica&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Mm9GVaSBOdHjaJ7wgfgG&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Elementa%20Harmonica&f=false|author= A. Barker|title=The Science of Harmonics in Classical Greece|publisher=Cambridge University Press |date=13 Sep 2007 |isbn=1139468626| accessdate=2015-05-03}}(p.187 "Meibom, Westphal")</ref>
==Synopsis== The parts of harmonics:<ref name="Mitzi Dewhitt"/><ref name=" A. Barker"/><ref name="A Briggman">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=buEm81wj7VkC&pg=PA145&dq=Aristoxenus+Elements&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1FlHVaKnEJLSaOeCgLAB&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Aristoxenus%20Elements&f=false|author=A Briggman|title=Irenaeus of Lyons and the Theology of the Holy Spirit|publisher=Oxford University Press, ''Oxford Early Christian Studies'' |date=12 Jan 2012 |isbn=0199641536| accessdate=2015-05-04}}("Distantia & Landels")</ref>
(1) The Genera - the ways in which the differences between these are determined
(2) Distantia (Intervals) - the distinction of how these are differentiated
(3) Notes - ''dynameis''
(4) Systēmata - enumerating and distinguishing the types, and explaining how they are put together out of Notes and Intervals
(5) Tonoi (Modes) - including the relations between them
(6) Modulation
(7) Construction / Composition
===Discussion=== The term dynamis seems to have been originated by Aristoxenus. Dynamis (dynameis) are conventionally understood to have, amongst other meanings, power and potentiality. Sidoli contends in his review (c.f. ref.) that the initial use of the concept by Aristoxenus was rather "elusive" in the context of the meaning intended by him.<ref>Erik Nis Ostenfeld, Plato (''[[The Republic (Plato)|The Republic]] - Ergon and dynamis'')- [https://books.google.com/books?id=bqu1BwAAQBAJ&pg=PT268&lpg=PT268&dq=dynameis++definition&source=bl&ots=CsatTOqI2j&sig=EhRILpHCIH_axMFxAbG02BXA2xo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=IcdMVeb4PMqX7QbTmoCoAQ&ved=0CFAQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=dynameis%20%20definition&f=false Forms, Matter and Mind] ''Volume 10 of Martinus Nijhoff philosophy library'' Springer Science & Business Media, 1982 {{ISBN|940097681X}} [Retrieved 2015-05-08]</ref><ref>definitions taken from [http://biblehub.com/greek/1411.htm bible hub] - [[Strong's Concordance]] & [http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/dynamis Merriam-Webster] [Retrieved 2015-05-08]</ref><ref name="Nathan Sidoli, Andrew Barker">{{cite book |url=http://bmcr.brynmawr.edu/2009/2009-10-38.html|author=Nathan Sidoli, Andrew Barker |title=Andrew Barker, The Science of Harmonics in Classical Greece reviewed by Nathan Sidoli, Waseda University|publisher=Bryn Mawr Classical Review 2009.10.38| accessdate=2015-05-08}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Musical system of ancient Greece#Aristoxenus's tonoi|Aristoxenus's tonoi]]

[[File:Jules Migonney - Venus mauresque.jpg|thumbnail|right|upright=1.3|Exotic figures in Jules Migonney's ''Venus mauresque'']]
'''Exoticism''' (from 'exotic') is a trend in European art and design, whereby artists became fascinated with ideas and styles from distant regions, and drew inspiration from them. This often involved surrounding foreign cultures with mystique and fantasy which owed more to European culture than to the exotic cultures themselves: this process of glamorisation and stereotyping is called 'exoticization'.
==History of exoticism==
First stimulated by Eastern trade in the 16th and 17th centuries, interest in non-western (particularly "Oriental", i.e. Middle Eastern or Asian) art by Europeans became more and more popular following [[European colonialism]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Oshinsky|first=Sara J.|title=Exoticism in the Decorative Arts|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/exot/hd_exot.htm|publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art}}</ref>
The influences of Exoticism can be seen through numerous genres of this period, notably in music, painting, and decorative art. In music, exoticism is a genre in which the rhythms, melodies, or instrumentation are designed to evoke the atmosphere of far-off lands or ancient times (e.g. [[Maurice Ravel|Ravel's]] ''[[Daphnis et Chloé]]'' and ''Tzigane for Violin and Orchestra'', [[Claude Debussy|Debussy's]] ''Syrinx for Flute Solo'' or [[Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov|Rimsky-Korsakov's]] ''[[Capriccio espagnol]]''). Like orientalist subjects in 19th-century painting, exoticism in the decorative arts and interior decoration was associated with fantasies of opulence.
Exoticism, by one definition, is "the charm of the unfamiliar". Scholar [[Alden Jones]] defines exoticism in art and literature as the representation of one culture for consumption by another.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesmartset.com/article/article08060708.aspx|title=This Is Not a Cruise|author=Alden Jones|date=August 6, 2007|publisher=The Smart Set}}</ref> Victor Segalen's important "Essay on Exoticism" reveals Exoticism as born of the age of imperialism, possessing both aesthetic and ontological value, while using it to uncover a significant cultural "otherness".<ref>{{cite book|last=Segalen|first=Victor|title=Essay on Exoticism: An Aesthetics of Diversity|year=2002|publisher=Duke University Press|location=Durham}}</ref> An important and archetypical exoticist is the artist and writer [[Paul Gauguin]], whose visual representations of [[Tahiti]]an people and landscapes were targeted at a French audience. While exoticism is closely linked to [[Orientalism]], it is not a movement necessarily associated with a particular time period or culture. Exoticism may take the form of [[primitivism]], [[ethnocentrism]], or humanism.
Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres (29 August 1780 – 14 January 1867) was a French Neoclassical painter. The revival of ancient Greek and Roman art left behind the Academy’s emphasis on naturalism, and incorporated a new found idealism not seen since the Renaissance.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Herbert|first=Robert|title=Art, Leisure, and Parisian Society|journal=Art Journal|year=1990|volume=49|issue=1|page=65}}</ref> As classicism progressed, Ingres identified a newfound idealism and exoticism in his work. The Grand Odalisque, finished in 1814, was created to arouse the male view.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Carter|first=Karen|title=The Spectatorship of the Affiche Illustrée and the Modern City of Paris, 1880-1900|journal=Journal of Design History|year=2012|volume=25|issue=1|page=24|doi=10.1093/jdh/epr044}}</ref> The notion of the exotic figure furthers Ingres’ use of symmetry and line by enabling the eye to cohesively move across the canvas.<ref>{{cite book|last=Chu|first=Petra|title=Nineteenth-Century European Art|year=2011|publisher=Prentice Hall|location=New Jersey|page=87}}</ref> Although Ingres’ intention was to make the woman beautiful in his work, his model was a courtesan, which arouse debate.
Édouard Manet’s [[Olympia (Manet)|Olympia]], finished in 1863, was based on Titian’s Venus of Urbino.<ref>{{cite book|last=Chu|first=Petra|title=Nineteenth Century European Art|year=2011|publisher=Prentice Hall|location=New Jersey|page=233}}</ref> Olympia was a popular play about a courtesan called Olympia. This subject was extremely controversial for an artist to portray a woman like this because of traditional vision of the Academy. Manet was being very different from the accepted academic style by outlining and flattening space that created a distortion of classical elements. Olympia is provocative in her nudity that implies she is naked, not nude.<ref>{{cite book|last=Chu|first=Petra|title=Nineteenth Century European Art|year=2011|publisher=Prentice Hall|location=New Jersey|page=235}}</ref> She is looking out in a very confrontational way, and setting the viewer as a man coming to the prostitute, although Olympia’s hand suggests she is not ready to engage with the customer.<ref>{{cite book|last=Chu|first=Petra|title=Nineteenth Century European Art|year=2011|publisher=Prentice Hall|location=New Jersey|page=236}}</ref> The African servant calls on racism and slavery in France, because showing someone of color participating in French life was unheard of, furthering the work's exotic nature.
==See also== * [[Chinoiserie]] * [[Orientalism]] * [[Other (philosophy)]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== * ''[https://www.jstor.org/stable/2739196 George Rousseau and Roy Porter]'' (1990). ''Exoticism in the Enlightenment'' (Manchester: Manchester University Press). {{ISBN|0-567-09330-1}} * [http://www.thesmartset.com/article/article08060708.aspx The Smart Set: Alden Jones on Teaching Exoticism on Semester at Sea] *Segalen, Victor. ''Essay on Exoticism: An Aesthetics of Diversity''. Trans. Yaël Rachel Schlick. Durham: Duke University Press, 2002.

{{Infobox school |image = |name = Hack Reactor |city = [[San Francisco]] and [[Los Angeles, California]]; [[Austin, Texas]]; [[New York City, New York]] |country = [[United States|USA]] |type = [[Private school|Private]] |motto = The CS degree for the 21st century |established = 2012 |founders = Anthony Phillips, Shawn Drost, Marcus Phillips, and Douglas Calhoun |faculty = 60+ |students = |campus = [[urban area|Urban]] |accreditation = none<ref name=Downs131013>{{cite news|last1=Downs|first1=David|title=Elite S.F. coding bootcamp fast-tracks programming training|url=http://archives.sfexaminer.com/sanfrancisco/elite-sf-coding-bootcamp-fast-tracks-programming-training/Content?oid=2602335|accessdate=2 July 2015|work=[[The San Francisco Examiner]]|publisher=San Francisco Media Company LLC|date=13 October 2013}}</ref> |website= [http://www.hackreactor.com/ hackreactor.com] }}
'''Hack Reactor''' is a [[software engineering]] [[Coding Bootcamp]] <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.coursereport.com/schools/hack-reactor|title=Course Report: Hack Reactor|date=2016|website=Course Report|quote=Founded in 2012, Hack Reactor is a 12-week immersive coding school in San Francisco providing software engineering education, career placement services, and a lifelong network of professional peers.|accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> education program founded in [[San Francisco]] by Anthony Phillips, Shawn Drost, Marcus Phillips, and Douglas Calhoun in 2012.<ref name=TGM150411>{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Alicia|title=Hack Reactor seeks to bridge the technology divide|url=http://techgenmag.com/2015/04/11/hack-reactor-seeks-to-bridge-the-technology-divide/|accessdate=2 July 2015|work=Tech Generation Magazine|date=11 April 2015|location=Long Beach, CA}}</ref> Their coding bootcamp is currently offered in 12-week Full-Time and 9-month Part-Time formats, in-person in San Francisco, Los Angeles, New York City and Austin, as well as remotely, live online.
Cofounder Drost has described the program as, "optimized for people who want to be software engineers as their main, day-to-day work. Their life's work."<ref name=Downs131013/> The curriculum focuses on [[JavaScript]] and associated technologies including the MEAN stack, React and Backbone.<ref name="BI130614">{{cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/hot-education-startups-2013-6?op=1|title=12 New Companies That Will Make Going To College Unnecessary|date=14 June 2013|work=[[Business Insider]]|last1=Russell|first1=Kyle|accessdate=2 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://techbeacon.com/complete-guide-top-24-coding-bootcamps|title=Complete Guide to the top 24 Coding Bootcamps|website=TechBeacon|access-date=2016-06-20}}</ref>
In 2015 Hack Reactor acquired Austin-based [[MakerSquare]] as "their first deal in a plan to develop a network of coding bootcamps" in an effort to "make a large dent in transforming the old education system into one that focuses on student outcomes."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Newman|first1=Kira M.|title=Coding Bootcamp Hack Reactor Acquires MakerSquare|url=http://tech.co/coding-bootcamp-hack-reactor-acquires-makersquare-2015-01|website=Tech Cocktail|accessdate=2 July 2015|date=21 January 2015}}</ref> The following month, a pair of Hack Reactor alumni partnered with the company to open Telegraph Academy "to teach software engineering to under-represented minorities" and create a "growing community of diverse software engineers."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.telegraphacademy.com/|title=Telegraph Academy the Leading Coding School for People of Color.|website=Telegraph Academy|access-date=2016-06-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Dugdale|first1=Emily|title=Berkeley coding school aims to help close tech race gap|url=http://www.berkeleyside.com/2015/06/22/berkeley-coding-school-telegraph-academy-launches-aimed-at-people-of-color/|website=Berkeleyside|accessdate=2 July 2015|date=22 June 2015}}</ref> In November 2016, Hack Reactor rebranded all of its schools to share the Hack Reactor name.<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc-7.com/story/33548858/hack-reactor-unifies-its-network-of-coding-schools-under-flagship-brand|title=Hack Reactor Unifies Its Network of Coding Schools under Flagship Brand|access-date=2016-12-06}}</ref>
== Admissions process == Hack Reactor's admissions standard has been described as "highly selective, only accepting ten to fifteen percent of applicants for each cohort."<ref name="TGM150411" /> Though many applicants who do not pass the first admission interview are encouraged to try again when they feel they are better prepared.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.quora.com/Did-Hack-Reactor-become-a-group-full-of-elitists#ans13162184|title=Did Hack Reactor become a group full of elitists?|last1=Pethiyagoda|first1=Ruan|date=9 June 2015|website=Quora|accessdate=2 July 2015}}</ref>
As of 2017, Hack Reactor has two admissions paths. Students can either self-study and pass a technical interview or join their Structured Study Program, a live class which includes preparation, readiness assessment and admittance.
The technical interview tests both technical skills (JavaScript basics such as objects, arrays, functions and the ability to solve basic coding problems using JavaScript) and soft skills, such as the student’s willingness and ability to learn.
Hack Reactor has created financial partnerships with SkillsFund and Climb Credit and to assist students with paying tuition.<ref name="hackreactor.com">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hackreactor.com/questions|title=FAQ|website=Coding Bootcamp in San Francisco. JavaScript focused programming school.|access-date=2016-06-13}}</ref> As of 2016, [[WeFinance]] and Reactor Core (Hack Reactor's parent company) have launched a platform that allows anyone to lend to incoming students.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wefinance.co/group/reactor_core|title=Lend to the Reactor Core Family|website=www.wefinance.co|access-date=2016-06-13}}</ref>
== Course Structure == Accepted students are assigned pre-course work, which takes "at least 50-80 hours" and is due prior to the start of their cohort.<ref name=":3" />
Hack Reactor’s course is offered in 12-week full-time and 9-month part-time formats. During the first half of the program, students work in pairs on two-day “sprints.” Pair and group work helps teach communication and collaboration skills. During this part of the course, the day typically starts with a “toy problem,” which is a programming challenge designed to illustrate core concepts.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.computerpoweruser.com/article/19555/qa-with-phillip-alexander|title=Q&A with Phillip Alexander|last=|first=|date=2016-12-28|website=Computer Power User|publisher=Computer Power User|access-date=2016-06-20}}</ref> This is followed by a lecture in which the instructor frequently checks in with students to assess how well they understand the material.<ref name=":0" /> The JavaScript tools and technologies taught at Hack Reactor include [[AngularJS|Angular]], [[Node.js|Node]], [[MongoDB]], [[Express.js|Express]], [[React (JavaScript library)|React]], [[Backbone.js|Backbone]] and [[ECMAScript|ES6]].<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.coursereport.com/blog/hack-reactor-vs-makersquare-your-ultimate-guide|title=Hack Reactor vs MakerSquare: Your Ultimate Guide|website=www.coursereport.com|access-date=2016-06-13}}</ref> The goal of this part of the course is for students to become “autonomous learners and programmers.”<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.coursereport.com/schools/hack-reactor#/news/instructor-spotlight-fred-zirdung-of-hack-reactor|title=Hack Reactor Reviews {{!}} Course Report|website=www.coursereport.com|access-date=2016-06-20}}</ref>
The second half of the course focuses on projects. Students complete “increasingly elaborate” coding projects of their own design, using whatever languages and frameworks they choose. Students often adopt technologies not taught in the course using “fundamentals and self-teaching methods” taught in the first half of the course.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://techbeacon.com/complete-guide-top-24-coding-bootcamps|title=Complete guide to the top 24 coding bootcamps|website=TechBeacon|access-date=2016-06-20}}</ref>
== Student Outcomes == Co-Founder Shawn Drost says that Hack Reactor is "committed to being the leading coding immersive in terms of quality, student experience and student outcomes." In 2017, they joined a 501(c)(6) non-profit organization called the Council on Integrity in Results Reporting (CIRR) as a founding member.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hackreactor.com/blog/hack-reactor-cirr-outcomes-reporting|title=CIRR Raises the Bar in Student Outcomes Reporting|work=Hack Reactor|access-date=2018-04-27|language=en-US}}</ref> CIRR requires members to report "the outcomes of every enrolled student must be reported in a single, simple, clear report" using common standards and follow "CIRR Truth in Advertising policies".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cirr.org/standards|title=High standards and a commitment to transparency and accountability. - Council on Integrity in Results Reporting (CIRR)|website=cirr.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-27}}</ref>
== Hack Reactor Remote == In July 2014, Hack Reactor launched an online program, Hack Reactor Remote. This program has the same curriculum, course structure and teaching method as Hack Reactor’s onsite program. Students attend and participate in the lectures at the same time as the other students, work on the same assignments, and benefit from the same job search and placement resources as the onsite program.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2014/06/16/hack-reactor-is-launching-an-online-coding-bootcamp-but-you-still-need-to-quit-life-to-do-it/|title=Hack Reactor is launching an online coding bootcamp, but you still need to quit life to do it|website=VentureBeat|access-date=2016-06-13}}</ref> Hack Reactor's Remote program has comparable student outcomes to its in-person campuses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hackreactor.com/outcomes|title=Student Outcomes & Graduate Performance|website=Hack Reactor|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-27}}</ref>
In 2017, Hack Reactor began offering a part-time version of their remote program, known as Hack Reactor Remote Part-Time.
== MakerSquare Acquisition == In January 2015, Hack Reactor acquired coding bootcamp MakerSquare, which had locations in Austin and San Francisco.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2015/01/coding-bootcamp-boom-continues-hack-reactor-buy/|title=Hack Reactor Expands Its Code Bootcamps by Acquiring a Rival|website=WIRED|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-13}}</ref> MakerSquare has since expanded into Los Angeles and New York City.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/technology/la-fi-tn-makersquare-los-angeles-20150408-story.html|title=MakerSquare to open L.A. campus to train software engineers|last=Times|first=Los Angeles|website=latimes.com|access-date=2016-06-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/makersquare-school-of-software-engineering-launches-new-york-city-campus-300233910.html|title=MakerSquare School of Software Engineering Launches New York City Campus|last=|first=|date=10 March 2016|website=PR Newswire|publisher=PR Newswire|access-date=10 March 2016}}</ref>
MakerSquare has the same admissions process, hiring partner network, and the same curriculum with a few small modifications.<ref name=":3" /> In November 2016, they rebranded to share the Hack Reactor name.<ref name=":5" />
== Social Responsibility ==
=== Code.7370 === In collaboration with The Last Mile, Hack Reactor launched Code.7370, a coding program in San Quentin State Prison. Inmates have to apply to be a part of the program. Once accepted, they learn HTML, CSS, Python and JavaScript for 8 hours a day, 4 days a week.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.fastcoexist.com/3038589/the-prison-coding-class-that-might-have-inmates-making-six-figures-on-their-release|title=The Prison Coding Class That Might Have Inmates Making Six Figures On Their Release|date=2014-11-17|website=Co.Exist|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-13}}</ref> Hack Reactor instructors volunteered as teachers. In addition to class time students are also given time to work on personal projects.<ref name=":4" /> Because inmates are not permitted access to the internet, Code.7370 operates by a proprietary programming platform that simulates a normal web environment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thelastmile.org/|title=The Last Mile – Paving The Road to Success|website=thelastmile.org|access-date=2016-06-13}}</ref> The goal of Code.7370 is to reduce recidivism and help felons reenter the workforce.
=== ReBootKAMP === Hack Reactor helped launch ReBootKAMP, a coding bootcamp in Jordan that focuses on Syrian refugees.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.barakabits.com/2016/01/rebooting-lives-syrian-refugees-rebootkamp|title=Rebooting the lives of Syrian Refugees-ReBootKAMP - BarakaBits|date=2016-01-31|website=BarakaBits|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-13}}</ref> ReBootKAMP uses Hack Reactor’s curriculum, and received volunteer assistance from Hack Reactor staff and alumni.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://rbk.org/|title=RBK {{!}} Empowering Youth For Positive Change|website=rbk.org|access-date=2016-06-13}}</ref> ReBootKAMP executives also received training on coding bootcamp best practices from Hack Reactor and Reactor Core.
=== Hola<nowiki><code/></nowiki> === In December 2017, Hack Reactor supported the launch of Hola<nowiki><code/></nowiki>, a coding bootcamp based in Mexico City focused on bringing new opportunities to recent returnees. Hola<nowiki><code/></nowiki> is powered by Hack Reactor curriculum and Hack Reactor alumni have been part of their teaching team.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hackreactor.com/blog/founders-letter|title=5 Years Forward - Hack Reactor's Founders, CEO Celebrate Past, Present, and Great Future|work=Hack Reactor|access-date=2018-04-27|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://holacode.com/ |title=Hola<code/> |access-date=2018-04-27}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Web Development]] * [[MakerSquare]]

{{Essay-like|date=November 2018}} [[File:PacificYew 7684.jpg|thumb|Pacific yew used for its anti-cancer properties]] '''Herbalism''' is the study of using plants for medicinal purposes and has dated back since the first humans arose around 100,000 to 200,000 years ago.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Li|first=Fu-Shuang|last2=Weng|first2=Jing-Ke|date=2017-07-31|title=Demystifying traditional herbal medicine with modern approach|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/nplants2017109.pdf|journal=Nature Plants|language=En|volume=3|issue=8|pages=17109|doi=10.1038/nplants.2017.109|issn=2055-0278}}</ref> Since then, [[herb]]s have been used by cultures across the world to treat a variety of ailments and diseases. As modern medicine has progressed, traditional practices of [[herbalism]] have been considered{{by whom|date= November 2018}} to be primitive and archaic. But with the rise of new technology, the invaluable information accumulated by this practice in combination with [[biotechnology]] could be used to open up new way of approaching medicine through expanding the current library of compounds to be used for pharmaceutical advancement and being able to develop new and effective treatments for complex diseases.
== History of herbalism == With the 400,000 of plant species known to date, there are many [[metabolite]]s derived from plants that can be applied to human biology from curing headaches to [[autoimmune disease]]s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://modernherbalmedicine.com/articles/natural-approaches-to-autoimmune-disorders.html|title=Natural Approaches to Autoimmune Disorders|website=modernherbalmedicine.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-28}}</ref> For instance, [[morphine]], a pain drug, comes from [[poppy]], while [[paclixatxel]], an anti-[[cancer]] drug, comes from [[pacific yew]]. Humans have used these properties of plants across numerous cultures and have accumulated a rich collection of data on the causes and effects of certain plants on the human body. This gave rise to the practice of herbalism, which in the past served as many cultures’ primary method of dealing with ailments. The first written records of herbalism date back to [[Ancient Egypt]] around 1,500 BC in the [[Papyrus Ebers]] where more than 800 plant medicines and their effects on the human body were documented.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/ShenNongBenCaoLingTheDivineFarmersMateriaMedica/ShenNong%20Ben%20Cao%20ling(The%20Divine%20Farmers%20Materia%20Medica)_djvu.txt|title=Full text of "Shen Nong Ben Cao Ling(The Divine Farmers Materia Medica)"|website=archive.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-28}}</ref> The Compendium of Materia Medica, written by [[Li Shizhen]], a Chinese herbalist of the sixteenth century, contains information on 1,893 different herbs and 11,096 prescriptions, demonstrating the breadth of knowledge accumulated on herbalism.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.ucpress.edu/ebook/9780520959743/the-ben-cao-gang-mu|title=The Ben Cao Gang Mu|language=en}}</ref> In many cultures, herbalism is often tied with spirituality. For example, in African culture, it is believed that healing is a religious act, while in the Chinese culture, vital energy (qi) and the balance between yin and yang play a crucial role in healing. Perhaps due to the lack of scientific evidence, herbalist practices has been disregarded, but it is no accident that so many cultures from across the world have chosen to treat disease through plants. Plants hold many biological solutions that can be applied to humans and paralleled with years of trial and error on behalf of herbalists to harness this information, herbalism has the potential to revolutionize modern medicine.
== Modern herbalism == Currently, many of the treatments approved by the [[FDA]] are single-compounds and do not have the ability to treat complex issues such as cancer or [[type II diabetes]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Patridge|first=Eric|last2=Gareiss|first2=Peter|last3=Kinch|first3=Michael S.|last4=Hoyer|first4=Denton|date=February 2016|title=An analysis of FDA-approved drugs: natural products and their derivatives|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25617672|journal=Drug Discovery Today|volume=21|issue=2|pages=204–207|doi=10.1016/j.drudis.2015.01.009|issn=1878-5832|pmid=25617672}}</ref> However, many of the prescriptions found in herbalism use multiple ingredients mixed in a specific ratio to be synergistic. This is known as the combinatorial effect and it is hypothesized that through multiple metabolites targeting many different sites, the simultaneous action has the potential to cure these complex diseases.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Kiyohara|first=Hiroaki|last2=Matsumoto|first2=Tsukasa|last3=Yamada|first3=Haruki|date=June 2004|title=Combination Effects of Herbs in a Multi-herbal Formula: Expression of Juzen-taiho-to's Immuno-modulatory Activity on the Intestinal Immune System|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC526207/|journal=Evidence-based Complementary and Alternative Medicine|volume=1|issue=1|pages=83–91|doi=10.1093/ecam/neh004|issn=1741-427X|pmid=15257329}}</ref> For example, a treatment called Food Allergy Herbal Formula-2 (FAHF-2) is currently under development to reduce [[peanut allergy|peanut allergies]]. Developed by Chinese scientist Xiu-Min Li, FAHF-2 was refined from an ancient traditional Chinese herbal prescription known as Wu Mei Wan, which was originally used to cure [[intestinal]] [[parasitic infection]]s but shares a similar mechanism as a [[food allergy]].<ref name=":1" /> It consists of nine different herbs and has shown in trial to be effective for curing food allergies. However, when these nine different herbs are used individually, the treatment is much less effective, demonstrating the power of the combinatorial effect.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Srivastava|first=Kamal D.|last2=Kattan|first2=Jacob D.|last3=Zou|first3=Zhong Mei|last4=Li|first4=Jing Hua|last5=Zhang|first5=Libang|last6=Wallenstein|first6=Sylvan|last7=Goldfarb|first7=Joseph|last8=Sampson|first8=Hugh A.|last9=Li|first9=Xiu-Min|date=January 2005|title=The Chinese herbal medicine formula FAHF-2 completely blocks anaphylactic reactions in a murine model of peanut allergy|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15637565|journal=The Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology|volume=115|issue=1|pages=171–178|doi=10.1016/j.jaci.2004.10.003|issn=0091-6749|pmid=15637565}}</ref> As many herbal prescriptions use the combinatorial effect, if this phenomenon can be analyzed and understood, many kinds of diseases could be cured with just a single prescription.
The power of herbalism has shown itself to be very promising, but perhaps in conjunction with new developments in biotechnology, it can be used to its full potential.
== Developments in biotechnology ==
=== Bioinformatic algorithms === [[Bioinformatics]] is the use of computers to solve biological problems specifically within the fields of [[macromolecular]] structures, [[genome]] sequences, and the results of functional genomics experiments, where large sets of data are involved. For example, they have been used to search a database of gene expression data sets from human cells treated with various small molecules.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lamb|first=Justin|last2=Crawford|first2=Emily D.|last3=Peck|first3=David|last4=Modell|first4=Joshua W.|last5=Blat|first5=Irene C.|last6=Wrobel|first6=Matthew J.|last7=Lerner|first7=Jim|last8=Brunet|first8=Jean-Philippe|last9=Subramanian|first9=Aravind|date=2006-09-29|title=The Connectivity Map: Using Gene-Expression Signatures to Connect Small Molecules, Genes, and Disease|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/313/5795/1929|journal=Science|language=en|volume=313|issue=5795|pages=1929–1935|doi=10.1126/science.1132939|issn=0036-8075|pmid=17008526}}</ref> This database allows researchers to find patterns between small molecules and their mechanisms of action and can be applied to the field of herbalism through identifying the medicinal properties of plant compounds. For instance, this technology aided in the discovery of [[celastrol]], a compound extracted from plant called ''[[Tripterygium wilfordi]]'' commonly used in traditional traditional Chinese medicine as a [[leptin]] sensitizer used to control obesity. Gene expression signatures of lean and obese mice were compared and through analysis researchers determined that celsastrol was the top compound in the database that correlated with anti-leptin resistance. Later, celastrol was tested in mice and shown to reduce obesity and could potentially be used as a treatment for obesity in humans. This example demonstrates the power of plant metabolites and how valuable knowledge of herbalism can as new technology such as bioinformatic algorithms are employed.
=== Crystalline sponge method === X-ray single-crystal diffraction is often used to identify and analyze structures of compounds which is an important step to analyzing existing herbal prescriptions to develop new medications. However, this method has key restrictions which limit its use. X-ray single-crystal diffraction requires the sample to be obtained as single [[crystal]]s and in larger quantities. The crystalline sponge method would allow the sample to be aqueous and also requires as little as 80 nanograms of the sample.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Inokuma|first=Yasuhide|last2=Yoshioka|first2=Shota|last3=Ariyoshi|first3=Junko|last4=Arai|first4=Tatsuhiko|last5=Hitora|first5=Yuki|last6=Takada|first6=Kentaro|last7=Matsunaga|first7=Shigeki|last8=Rissanen|first8=Kari|last9=Fujita|first9=Makoto|date=2013-03-28|title=X-ray analysis on the nanogram to microgram scale using porous complexes|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23538828?dopt=Abstract&holding=npg|journal=Nature|volume=495|issue=7442|pages=461–466|doi=10.1038/nature11990|issn=1476-4687|pmid=23538828}}</ref> The technology uses networked porous metal complexes which have high molecule-recognition ability that can absorb molecules from an aqueous solution and order them regularly in the crystal.<ref name=":2" /> This way, the molecule can be analyzed with x-ray diffraction and provides a much higher accuracy than [[nuclear magnetic resonance]] (NMR) and [[mass spectrometry]].<ref name=":2" /> With this technology, researchers were able to uncover the complete stereochemistry of miyakosyne A, a scarce natural marine product. Due to the small structural difference between one [[methylene]] unit, chemical and spectroscopic methods were not precise enough to determine its exact structure, making x-ray diffraction the only viable method. A tiny crystal sponge of approximately 100 by 100 by 100 µm3 was treated with 5 mg of miyakosyne A and analyzed with x-ray diffraction.<ref name=":2" /> This allowed the complete structure of miyakosyne A to be revealed, making researchers hopeful for its application in a variety of its fields, including herbalism. As many organic compounds from plants must first be dried into a powder and in large quantities before analysis or analyzed through inaccurate methods such as NMR or mass spectrometry, the crystalline sponge method would greatly simplify the process of identifying compounds of interest. As a result, this would make it easier for researchers to study specific metabolites and their potential applications.
=== Combinatorial biosynthesis === Combinatorial biosynthesis is the use of engineered enzymes and pathways to produce different metabolites as opposed traditional chemical synthesis, which is costly, inefficient, and produces byproduct waste.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Sun|first=Huihua|last2=Liu|first2=Zihe|last3=Zhao|first3=Huimin|last4=Ang|first4=Ee Lui|date=2015-02-12|title=Recent advances in combinatorial biosynthesis for drug discovery|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4334309/|journal=Drug Design, Development and Therapy|volume=9|pages=823–833|doi=10.2147/DDDT.S63023|issn=1177-8881|pmc=4334309|pmid=25709407}}</ref> So, in the context of herbalism, if a specific metabolite is scare in its herbal form, it can be produced through combinatorial synthesis to create a cheap and eco-friendly treatment. Currently, there are three major strategies for combinatorial biosynthesis: precursor-directed biosynthesis, enzyme-level modification, and pathway-level recombination.<ref name=":3" />
Precursor-directed biosynthesis creates different metabolites through using different substrates through the same metabolic pathway. Because pathways are promiscuous and non-substrate specific, nonnative substrates can be integrated into the pathway to produce useful variations of metabolites.<ref name=":3" /> If this approach is used to manipulate the metabolic pathway of certain herbs, it could lead to new drug discovery.
The second strategy for combinatorial biosynthesis is enzyme-level modification, entailing either swapping entire domains, modules, or subunits, site-specific [[mutagenesis]], or directed evolution. Swapping entire domains, modules, or subunits of [[enzyme]]s is the classical approach of combinatorial biosynthesis and allows for the direct editing of enzymes in a specific pathway, resulting in new metabolites.<ref name=":3" /> Site-specific mutagenesis is the modification of individual amino acids in a sequence. Compared to the previous technique, it is less invasive, leading to higher yields of viable protein.<ref name=":3" /> By introducing a single mutation, the substrate specificity of the protein can change, which could improve drugs and even make natural substances found in plants more effective at treating disease. Directed evolution takes a similar approach to site-specific mutagenesis, but creates larger alterations.<ref name=":3" /> As a result, new metabolites can emerge with and make existing treatments even more effective.
The final strategy for combinatorial biosynthesis is pathway-level recombination. This is the editing of the pathway itself. Pathway-level recombination is performed through using biosynthetic genes from different species of organisms to create a pathways in a host organism.<ref name=":3" /> This technique often used to edit yeast so they can produce metabolites of interest from rare herbs or plants.
